Variational low bound

January 20, 2025

The variational lower bound (ELBO) is defined as:

$$
\mathcal{L}{\text{VAE}} = \mathbb{E}{q_\phi(z|x)} \left[ \log p_\theta(x|z) \right] - \text{KL} \left( q_\phi(z|x) | p(z) \right)
$$

where:

  • qϕ(z|x): Approximate posterior distribution of the latent variable z, parameterized by ϕ (the encoder).
  • pθ(x|z): Likelihood of the observed data x, conditioned on z, parameterized by θ (the decoder).
  • $ \mathbb{E}{q\phi(z|x)} :Expectationwithrespectto q_\phi(z|x) $.
  • KL(qϕ(z|x)|p(z)): Kullback-Leibler divergence between qϕ(z|x) and the prior p(z).
  • p(z): Prior distribution of the latent variable z (commonly a standard Gaussian N(0,I)).

Interpretation:

  1. The term $ \mathbb{E}{q\phi(z|x)} \left[ \log p_\theta(x|z) \right] encouragesthemodeltoreconstructtheinputdata x accuratelyfromthelatentvariable z $.
  2. The term KL(qϕ(z|x)|p(z)) regularizes the latent space by ensuring that the approximate posterior qϕ(z|x) remains close to the prior p(z).
  3. Maximizing LVAE ensures a balance between accurate reconstruction and a smooth, interpretable latent space.
  4. | (double vertical bars) in KL divergence indicates the divergence between two probability distributions.
    Explanation:
  • KL divergence measures how much one distribution differs from another.
  • If qϕ(z|x) and p(z) are identical, the KL divergence becomes zero.
  • It penalizes the model when qϕ(z|x) deviates too much from the prior p(z), promoting a regularized latent space.

# ELBO (Maximization Form)

The ELBO is defined as:
$$
\mathcal{L}{\text{VAE}} = \mathbb{E}{q_\phi(z|x)} \left[ \log p_\theta(x|z) \right] - \text{KL} \left( q_\phi(z|x) | p(z) \right)
$$

  • The goal is to maximize this objective.

# VAE Loss (Minimization Form)

To convert it into a loss for minimization:
$$
\text{Loss} = -\mathbb{E}{q\phi(z|x)} \left[ \log p_\theta(x|z) \right] + \text{KL} \left( q_\phi(z|x) | p(z) \right)
$$

  • The likelihood term ( \mathbb{E}{q\phi(z|x)}[\log p_\theta(x|z)] ) is positive in the ELBO, but negated to be part of the loss.
  • The KL divergence is inherently non-negative, so it's directly added to the loss.

# Why Minimize?

Minimizing this loss:

  1. Encourages accurate reconstruction of ( x ) (by maximizing ( \log p_\theta(x|z) )).
  2. Regularizes the latent space (by minimizing ( \text{KL}(q_\phi(z|x) | p(z)) )).

Thus, while the ELBO is maximized, the loss is its negative form, and we minimize it in practice.
